# Blueshield Officer
The [color=#28a]Blueshield Officer[/color] is an elite bodyguard unit sent by [color=#282]Central Command[/color], tasked with protecting the [color=yellow]Heads of Staff[/color] and designated [color=yellow]VIPs[/color] aboard the station.
As the station's BSO you are part of the [color=yellow]Command[/color] department; and are, foremost, tasked with protecting fellow members of Command. You are however, sent by [color=#282]CentComm[/color], and are part of Central Command. Meaning you can technically refuse orders from the [color=yellow]Captain[/color], if they go against the interests of NanoTrasen.
### Communicating Your headset starts with the [color=#2f2]Common[/color] and [color=yellow]Command[/color] encryption keys, and you can ask heads of staff for spares of their department's radio key, your unique headset can fit [color=yellow]5 keys total[/color], as opposed to the standard 4 of most other models. You can't be in every department at once, to protect every head, so it's a good idea to communicate on when and where you should be when things start getting scary.
Additionally, your headset starts with a [color=#28a]Central Command encryption key[/color], which functions without a dedicated telecomms server and works sectors apart; working as a direct, long range link between you and CentComm, allowing you to speak to officials across space. [bold]There isn't always someone manning the line[/bold], so you might need to get Central's attention with a stamped fax, unless they make contact first.
Your locker also starts with an [color=#28a]encryption key case[/color] housing one (1) spare CC encryption key. It's a good idea to hand it off to a member of command or otherwise a [bold]very[/bold] trusted person, as it can serve as a powerful tactical utility.
### Fighting
As a Blueshield Officer you are issued the [color=#3cf]Gendarme energy pistol[/color] as well as a belt to holster it, similar to the Captain's sabre.
The Gendarme features a [color=yellow]self-recharging battery[/color] and two separate [color=yellow]fire modes[/color] it can switch between. A [color=yellow]full charge[/color] is enough for [color=red]6 lethal shots[/color] or [color=#3cf]12 nonlethal shots[/color].
The Gendarme can fire energy bolts in a [color=red]lethal[/color] & [color=#3cf]non-lethal[/color] configuration; both modes deal [color=#3cf]stamina damage[/color] and pass through glass. the lethal configuration deals less stamina damage than the dedicated non-lethal configuration.
You also start with standard issue [color=yellow]Mk 58 pistol[/color] with 2 magazines, [color=yellow]jackboots[/color] with a [color=yellow]combat knife[/color] inside, and insulated [color=yellow]combat gloves[/color], meaning you have more traditional, more material combat options to rely on.
Your locker comes with a random set of surplus [color=yellow]nonlethal grenades[/color], which when used wildly, can work as stellar defensive utilities. Forcing enemies to work around them buying you and anyone you're guarding crucial time to fall back.
You are also issued the [color=yellow]SWAT helmet[/color], and a unique [color=yellow]armored voidsuit[/color]. The helmet is stronger than those in security; and your voidsuit, while not providing much more resistance than your standard body armor, is the [color=yellow]fastest spaceproof combat suit[/color] the crew has access to, trading protection for agility in making it to where you're needed most, escorting a VIP during a crisis. Use these advantages wisely.
### The End Your gear has many unique advantages, use them wisely - and you will be hailed a hero by command and your supervisors.
Stand ready for special orders from [color=#282]Central Command[/color], if such arrive.
The right man in the wrong place, makes all the difference in the world.
Now get out there! A tider might be trying to murk the CMO again. DISMISSED!
